column512:
Vagamon Orchidarium & Floriculture Project is a botanical garden situated at Kolahalamedu in the hill town of Vagamon. Located near Vagamon Pine Forest, it is one of the must-visit Vagamon tourist places.

Spread across 15-hectare (37-acre), it is known as the first orchid garden in Kerala. This was opened to the public in 2014 by the KFDC. The garden has some rare varieties of orchids that are found in the Western Ghats. The Orchidarium is a real paradise for those who love flowers and are interested in growing Orchids and roses.

Vagamon Orchidarium has more than 3000 varieties of both indoor and outdoor orchids, 200 varieties of roses, hydrangeas, Bougainville and various other plants. Apart from the plants and flowers, this land is a collection of small meadows and a pond with open sitting and relaxing areas. The visitors can purchase Orchid and other flowers, seeds, from Orchidarium. There is an Eco shop from which visitors can buy Cardamom, Coffee, Pepper, Honey, Sandalwood, Sandal oil, Sandal Powder, Red Sandal, and many more. The Evo shop also offers refreshments like tea, coffee, ice cream etc in association with Milma.

Timings: 8 AM to 6 PM

Entry: Rs. 25 for Adults, Rs. 15 for Children.

A must visit place for people who visit Vagamon.

Some of the places from photos shown in the map even with people in it are not safe to go, especially during the rains. 

Forest officials may take action against you if found violating the rules. Warning signs have been explicitly placed at least at some spots narrating the accidents occurred. This is for the safety of the visitors. There are many locations where you don't need specific permissions. And for some, you won't get permission anyway.

Please also note that as you go deeper, you'll find leeches. Keep moving in densely vegetated areas. Do not stand at one place for more than a few seconds. Keep handy a little amount of salt or snuff (മൂക്കിപൊടി) or tobacco leaves (പുകയില) & apply on the leech if it is on your body. If you're bitten, do not pull it forcefully to remove it or you might end up losing blood. Use shoes for a safer walk, though leeches can get on quicker & inside the clothes than you might think. The Idukki Dam is a double curvature arch dam constructed across the Periyar River in a narrow gorge between two granite hills locally known as Kuravan and Kurathi in Idukki district, Kerala, India. At 168.91 metres (554.2 ft), it is one of the highest arch dams in Asia. It is constructed and owned by the Kerala State Electricity Board. It supports a 780 MW hydroelectric power station in Moolamattom, which started generating power on 4 October 1975. The dam type is a concrete, double curvature parabolic, thin arc dam.The Indo-Canadian project was inaugurated by the Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on February 17, 1976.

This dam was constructed along with two other dams at Cheruthoni and Kulamavu. Together, the three dams and Two saddle dams, Kulamavu Saddle Dam (Near Junction) and Kulamavu Saddle Dam (Right Bank) have created an artificial lake that is 60 km2 (23 sq mi) in area. The stored water is used to produce electricity at the Moolamattom Power house, which is located inside nearby rocky caves.

Narakakkanam, Azhutha, Vazhikkadavu, Vadakkepuzha and Kuttiar diversion schemes were later added to augment the Idukki reservoir

Mattupetty Dam: A Picturesque Destination in the Western Ghats

Located in the picturesque Western Ghats of India, Mattupetty Dam is a must-visit destination for any traveler to Kerala. During my recent visit to the area, I was fortunate enough to spend an afternoon at this stunning location, and it was an unforgettable experience.

One of the first things I noticed about Mattupetty Dam was the breathtaking natural beauty that surrounded it. The dam is set against a stunning backdrop of lush green hills, and the cool, clear waters of the lake provided a soothing respite from the hot Indian sun.

The dam itself is an impressive feat of engineering, with a length of 1,700 meters and a height of 170 meters. It was built in the 1940s to provide water for the surrounding towns and villages, and it remains an important source of irrigation to this day.

One of the highlights of my visit to Mattupetty Dam was taking a leisurely boat ride on the tranquil waters of the lake. The boat ride allowed me to soak in the natural beauty of the area and provided a unique perspective on the dam and surrounding landscape. The cool breeze that swept over the lake was refreshing and invigorating, and I felt completely at peace surrounded by such stunning natural beauty.

Another highlight of my visit was the opportunity to see some of the local wildlife up close. The surrounding hills are home to a variety of flora and fauna, and I was lucky enough to spot some deer and wild goats grazing on the hillsides.

For those looking to learn more about the history and significance of the dam, there is also a small museum on site that provides an informative overview of the dam's construction and the important role it plays in the region.

Overall, my visit to Mattupetty Dam was a truly memorable experience that allowed me to connect with nature and appreciate the beauty of the Western Ghats.
